In 2021 and 2022, we supported several diversity programs and 
initiatives to enable long-term partnerships with minority and 
specialized patient communities and advocacy organizations. 
• Supported ResearcHERS, a program led by the American Cancer 
Society, which empowers women to help raise funds for women-led 
cancer research and recognize trailblazers in the field. Seagen’s 
Senior Vice President and Head of Late-Stage Development, Dr. 
Marjorie Green, spoke on reversing disparities experienced by 
women in STEM through supporting women-led cancer research. 
The video was shared via our social media channels. 
Seagen invested approximately $4 million in national 
patient advocacy organization support and activities for 
hematology-oncology, breast, bladder, cervical, gastric, 
colorectal, pan-tumor, minority health, and young adult 
advocacy communities.Cervical Cancer  
Geo-Analyzer
Seagen’s Health Economics & Outcomes Research (HEOR) 
team collaborated with Value Analytics Lab, subject matter 
experts, and advocates to develop the Cervical Cancer 
Geo-Analyzer, launched at the American Society of Clinical 
Oncology (ASCO) 2022 Annual Meeting. The Geo-Analyzer 
is an open access, web-based, interactive tool to visualize 
cervical cancer and recurrent or metastatic cervical cancer 
burden across the U.S. The tool aims to support researchers, 
policymakers, and advocacy groups in informing allocation 
of healthcare resources in areas where cervical cancer 
education or healthcare resource needs are high. More 
information on the tool can be found here.CASE STUDY• Sponsored the American Cancer Society’s Blue Button Pilot Project, 
a two-year initiative that seeks to minimize barriers obstructing 
patient participation in clinical trials through the proactive use of 
electronic health records. Seagen’s Clinical Operations leader, 
Gretchen Goller, is seated on the Advisory Committee.
• Partnered with Dia de la Mujer Latina, a community-based 
organization dedicated to promoting healthy behaviors within the 
underserved Latino community for 25 years. The organization’s 
founder Venus Gines participated in the “CeMe Campaign” to raise 
awareness about Cervical Cancer.
• Supported the Tigerlily Foundation’s Angels Advocacy Program, 
which provides comprehensive training to empower women of color 
to mobilize and advocate for health equity in their communities, 
including education around the value of clinical trial participation.
• Supported the Seattle Children’s pilot program aimed at helping 
underrepresented minorities.Tamika Felder, CeMe campaign participant and cancer survivor
Collaborative engagement with the patient advocacy community provides pathways to ensuring patient 
voices are heard in every step of research and innovation. These engagements are the sources for 
learning from the lived experiences of patients and caregivers, allowing us to more deeply understand 
the needs and values of people living with cancer, the challenges faced from their own perspectives 
and reveal the gaps we are positioned to fill as innovators, scientists, and developers.
KRISTIN OLSON  SENIOR DIRECTOR, PATIENT ADVOCACY
